newsitem.title: FRANCE: W.Bank wants "privatisation by voucher" in Algeria.
newsitem.headline: W.Bank wants "privatisation by voucher" in Algeria.

text.p: A World Bank official, praising Algeria's progress in stabilising its economy, wants the government to carry out a massive sell-off of state-owned firms through vouchers to lure small investors, an Algerian newspaper said on Tuesday.

World Bank regional director for the Maghreb, Daniel Ritchie, told Liberte newspaper the bank had several ways to support the government to implement reforms in the violence-ridden North African country.
He asked Algeria to speed up the sell-off of state-owned by "popular privatisation through the technique of widescale selling-off by vouchers," Liberte said.
Ritchie gave examples of Algerian industry factories still operating despite no one buying their products.
"Why this obstinacy to protect these jobs today at the cost of thousands of jobs which might be created tomorrow," he asked.

Outside Algeria's oil and gas industry, some 400 state firms are estimated overall to operate at only 35 percent capacity while an estimated 500 billion dinars ($9 billion) have been injected in them in the past seven years to try to save around 1.7 million jobs.

"Algeria has made huge progress in macro-economic stabilisation. I have been told that you are heading to reach a three percent rate in creating jobs, a positive growth rate for the second consecutive year and, above all, a budget surplus", he said.
Ritchie visited Algeria this week where he held talks with economy officials and toured several industry plants to get first hand look into the country's reforms, officials said.
Algeria's economy ministers will meet International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank officials later this month in Washington to assess Algeria's reform record.
The government said this week industrial sector production slumped by seven percent in the first half of 1996 compared to the same period of 1995.
Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyahia said the industrial stagnation underlined the "significance and the interest the country had to give to stabilise this important section of the economy."

Algeria posted a 4.4 percent growth in its Gross Domestic Product in the first half of 1996, a $1.3 billion trade surplus for the same period and has forecast a $300 million current account surplus for the whole year against a previous forecast $2 billion deficit.
